Award.AwardTitle: The developmental genetic basis for evolutionary variation in the hominin shoulder

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Evolutionary changes in the anatomy of the shoulder (shoulder blade and upper arm) are associated with some of the most important behavioral changes in modern humans and our hominin ancestors, such as reduced time spent in trees, increased tool use and manipulation, and incredibly accurate throwing. Considering much of evolution occurs via changes in how genes are turned on/off in the developing body, determining which genes and regulatory switches control shoulder development is of critical importance for understanding the genetic basis of skeletal shape and the sequence of events that has produced our unique shoulders. This project investigates the developmental and genetic mechanisms that control shoulder shape, by comparing shoulder shape in apes and humans, conducting experiments that will identify genes that are active during shoulder development, and analyzing these genetic data to reconstruct the unique evolution of the human shoulder. Broader impacts include training of underrepresented minority students, public science outreach through workshops and museum exhibits, and findings that may be informative for biomedical studies of shoulder dysfunction or disease.

The unique features of the human shoulder, consisting of the scapula and proximal humerus, evolved from an ancestral hominoid pattern, but recent fossils cast doubt as to the morphotype. In the human lineage, evolutionary shifts in shoulder morphology are associated with some of the most important behavioral changes in hominins, such as reduced arboreality, tool use and increased manipulation, and accurate throwing. The human shoulder is under strong developmental genetic programming in which key aspects of component positioning, orientation, and shape emerge in utero. This early shape morphogenesis is intriguing considering that the scapula arises from multiple cell populations, which condense and fuse to form integrated, yet morphologically distinct, bony elements, each of which is critical to adult function. Given this complexity, which developmental and genetic mechanisms control shoulder shape? Considering that much of phenotypic evolution occurs via changes in the non-coding regulatory genome, determining which genes and regulatory switches (e.g., enhancers) control shoulder morphogenesis is of critical importance for understanding the genetic basis of skeletal shape and for reconstructing the sequence of mutational events that has produced the unique human shoulder morphology. This proposal aims to illuminate developmental mechanisms contributing to the evolution of the human shoulder girdle using: 1) Geometric morphometrics including shape analyses and reconstructions of shoulder morphospaces in order to quantify and model evolutionary trajectories in shape variation in apes and humans; 2) RNA-seq and ChIP-seq experimental assays on embryonic mouse shoulder tissues to identify both genes and regulatory elements, respectively, that are differentially active in shoulder components; 3) comparative genomics on functionally identified sequences to identify base-pair differences between humans and chimps that contribute to shoulder variation; and 4) PAML likelihood ratio testing to identify phylogenetic timing of adaptive selection on functional coding and non-coding sequences and test alternative models of human shoulder evolution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Understanding the forces that influenced the evolution of human appendages, including both the shoulder and limbs, is an important part in deciphering what makes humans unique from other primates, such as chimpanzees and gorillas. Living and extinct primates exhibit differences in limb anatomy, reflecting different locomotor styles. In the human lineage, evolutionary changes in the shoulder are associated with some of the first and arguably most important behavioral changes in our ancestors, such as reduced time spent in trees and our increased reliance on tool use, manipulation, and throwing. Underlying skeletal changes are developmental modifications that reflect the actions of natural selection on the genetic processes that help build the limb and its girdle. This is apparent in that species-specific shapes are typically present early in development; a situation particularly true of shoulder anatomy. Specifically, in apes including humans, species-specific shoulder shape is identifiable in infants, with subsequent postnatal life having little effect on differences. However, little is known of the specific developmental and genetic mechanisms contributing to variation in prenatal shoulder development. In this study, we proposed a mechanistic framework to address the developmental origins and evolutionary timing of variation in human shoulders, specifically focusing on understanding the last common ancestor (LCA) of chimpanzees and humans and the transition to the modern human shoulder condition. This novel approach used data we generated on anatomical differences in shoulder morphology in living apes, combined with datasets we also generated from developmental genetics in mice to generate testable hypotheses about the origins and timing of key events in human shoulder evolution.

We approached this task using three approaches: (1) we sought to first quantify shape differences in the shoulder skeleton of apes, humans, and fossil species and we used these data to reconstruct evolutionary histories in shoulder shape change through humans. (2) We sought to identify the genetic factors (genes and their regulatory on/off DNA switches) that influence the development of human shoulder shape using the typical mammalian model system: the mouse. (3) We sought to understand the evolutionary changes in important DNA sequences to learn more about the timing and evolutionary events that led to the human unique shoulder anatomy.  Throughout the duration of this project we made substantial progress to each of these aims and revealed important aspects of human shoulder biology and evolution.

Regarding our approach (#1), we generated shoulder shape datasets for different apes, including humans, and then generated a detailed understanding of how different species vary in their shoulders. We then deciphered some “rules” of how shape change has proceeded over the course of human evolution from a LCA with chimpanzees. These findings also enabled us to test these evolutionary changes directly with the use of the fossil record on shoulders revealing that human shoulders evolved gradually over the course of evolution from a LCA with chimpanzees, rather than rapidly like other skeletal (pelvis) and non-skeletal (e.g., brain) organs. We also expanded this study to focus on the predicted performance of such shape variation to produce physical movements relevant to human shoulder use, both for living as well as extinct ancestors. This latter approach represents a significant advance in deriving testable predictions about the history of natural selection across the course of human shoulder evolution.

Regarding our approaches (#2-#3), using the mouse model to examine how the shoulder and other skeletal structures (control tissues such as the pelvis, arms, and legs) form prenatally, we made remarkable discoveries into the genes and on/off DNA switches used to drive development of different parts of each bone. For example, we used a routine technique called RNA-sequencing to detect genes specifically utilized in each part of the shoulder.  We also used a novel technique called ATAC-sequencing to identify specific on/off DNA switches in each part of the shoulder and other bones. For the shoulder and its parts (e.g., blade versus glenoid versus acromion) we found tens to hundreds of genes specifically expressed uniquely in each tissue in the early cartilage cells that help contribute to the shape of each part.  We also found hundreds to thousands of regulatory switches that help turn on/off these genes in each part. Collectively, we have built a catalogue of genes and switches that are used to build the shoulder as compared to other bones in the body. Using comparative approach that allows us to examine DNA sequences between humans, chimpanzees, other apes, and monkeys for each DNA switch in the catalogue, we have been able to identify over 50 switches that show evidence of having been under natural selection along the human lineage and which likely impact the morphology of the shoulder.  These sequences can also be examined for when they likely arose in humans and contributed to the development of the unique shoulder anatomy.
